articles.headline: Credit Suisse Pleads Guilty in Felony Case
articles.snippet: The Swiss bank, which has large investment banking operations in New York, will also pay about $2.6 billion in penalties and hire an independent monitor for up to two years.
articles.abstract: The Swiss bank, which has large investment banking operations in New York, will also pay about $2.6 billion in penalties and hire an independent monitor for up to two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:12 p.m. | Credit Suisse has done what no other bank of its size and significance has done in over two decades: plead guilty to criminal wrongdoing.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: For Workers, Less Flexible Companies
articles.snippet: Many employers say they offer telecommuting and flexible work hours to employees, but in fact are cutting back on time for child leave or to care for an ill parent.
articles.abstract: Many employers say they offer telecommuting and flexible work hours to employees, but in fact are cutting back on time for child leave or to care for an ill parent.
articles.lead_paragraph: He calls it one of the bright spots of his week: Before Jared Dalton, 32, starts his workday as a manager at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, he dresses his 5-month-old daughter, Olivia, and then places her on her tummy to play. Since he works from home on Mondays and Tuesdays, he can spend an extra hour with Olivia and an extra hour working — time that would otherwise be lost commuting into Manhattan.

articles.headline: AT&T-DirecTV Deal Churns Regulatory Waters
articles.snippet: While AT&T’s bid for DirecTV bears similarity to Comcast’s deal for Time Warner Cable, experts say the differences could lead regulators to separate conclusions for each one.
articles.abstract: While AT&T’s bid for DirecTV bears similarity to Comcast’s deal for Time Warner Cable, experts say the differences could lead regulators to separate conclusions for each one.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many supporters of the blockbuster Comcast-Time Warner Cable merger breathed a sigh of relief on Sunday, when AT&T and DirecTV announced plans to merge, thinking the latest pairing would divert some regulatory scrutiny of the other high-stakes deal.

articles.headline: In Tax Case, Credit Suisse Is Denied Milder Penalty
articles.snippet: After years of declining to charge big banks, prosecutors are now seeking to criminally punish the banks without putting them out of business and wreaking havoc on the financial system.
articles.abstract: After years of declining to charge big banks, prosecutors are now seeking to criminally punish the banks without putting them out of business and wreaking havoc on the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the eve of the year-end holidays, Credit Suisse’s top lawyer visited Washington to plead for mercy.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Ukraine Crisis Pushing Putin Toward China
articles.snippet: Conciliatory remarks on Ukraine by President Vladimir V. Putin were probably intended for China, where he arrives Tuesday determined to strengthen “mutually beneficial trade and economic ties.”
articles.abstract: Conciliatory remarks on Ukraine by President Vladimir V. Putin were probably intended for China, where he arrives Tuesday determined to strengthen “mutually beneficial trade and economic ties.”
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said Monday that he was withdrawing Russian troops from the border with Ukraine, the second time he has said that in less than two weeks. He also praised the government in Kiev, which he had previously called an illegal, fascist junta, for its willingness to negotiate structural changes.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Credit Suisse’s C.E.O. Is Called the ‘Teflon Man’
articles.snippet: A low-key Midwesterner, Brady W. Dougan has always been something of an anomaly on Wall Street. He is also the chief executive of the first very large bank to be criminally convicted in decades.
articles.abstract: A low-key Midwesterner, Brady W. Dougan has always been something of an anomaly on Wall Street. He is also the chief executive of the first very large bank to be criminally convicted in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brady W. Dougan, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, has always been something of an anomaly on Wall Street. He is a low-key Midwesterner who prefers long-distance running to New York City’s high-octane charity scene. When he married for the second time a few years ago, it was not to a much younger woman but to his high school sweetheart. He drives a Prius.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: For Activist Investors, a Wide Reporting Window
articles.snippet: In an age of activism, does a rule allowing 10 days to file with the S.E.C. when buying more than 5 percent of a company’s shares create an unfair advantage for large investors?
articles.abstract: In an age of activism, does a rule allowing 10 days to file with the S.E.C. when buying more than 5 percent of a company’s shares create an unfair advantage for large investors?
articles.lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman seemingly appeared out of nowhere.

articles.headline: Credit Suisse Investors Shrug Off Tax Plea
articles.snippet: Brady Dougan, the bank’s chief executive, said Credit Suisse took full responsibility for its actions, but said the bank had “found no instances where clients cannot do business with us.”
articles.abstract: Brady Dougan, the bank’s chief executive, said Credit Suisse took full responsibility for its actions, but said the bank had “found no instances where clients cannot do business with us.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:12 p.m. | A day after Credit Suisse pleaded guilty to tax evasion in the United States, the Swiss bank says that it is able to conduct its business as normal despite its criminal conviction. Swiss officials and investors seemed to welcome the fact that the resolution allows the bank to put the matter behind it.

articles.headline: Retaliatory Attacks, Online
articles.snippet: Standing against Beijing, or even alerting foreign governments to trade issues, can carry serious repercussions.
articles.abstract: Standing against Beijing, or even alerting foreign governments to trade issues, can carry serious repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Two large American steel makers, United States Steel and Allegheny Technologies, each lost confidential files in online attacks. The largest solar panel manufacturer in the United States, SolarWorld, lost technological secrets, production cost data, cash flow projections and details of its legal strategy.

articles.headline: Target Fires Chief of Unit in Canada, Which Lags
articles.snippet: The company, whose chief resigned just weeks ago, lost $941 million in Canada last year and has been dealing with a large data breach.
articles.abstract: The company, whose chief resigned just weeks ago, lost $941 million in Canada last year and has been dealing with a large data breach.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a year of public setbacks and damaging missteps, Target made another move on Tuesday to try to right itself by firing the president of its struggling Canadian division.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Ian Austen

articles.headline: V.A. Accusations Aggravate Woes of White House
articles.snippet: Republicans, eager to use allegations of misconduct at the nation’s veterans hospitals, seized on the reports as new evidence that President Obama is unable to govern effectively.
articles.abstract: Republicans, eager to use allegations of misconduct at the nation’s veterans hospitals, seized on the reports as new evidence that President Obama is unable to govern effectively.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House fought on Tuesday to contain the growing political furor over allegations of misconduct at the nation’s veterans hospitals as Republicans, eager to use the issue in the midterm elections, seized on the reports as new evidence that President Obama is unable to govern effectively.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jonathan Weisman
